#Text=CHAPTER II .
#Text=GOOD INDIAN
#Text=There is a saying -- and if it is not purely Western , it is at least purely American -- that the only good Indian is a dead Indian .

#Text=In the very teeth of that , and in spite of the fact that he was neither very good , nor an Indian -- nor in any sense “ dead” -- men called Grant Imsen “ Good Indian ” to his face ; and if he resented the title , his resentment was never made manifest -- perhaps because he had grown up with the name , he rather liked it when he was a little fellow , and with custom had come to take it as a matter of course .

#Text=Because his paternal ancestry went back , and back to no one knows where among the race of blue eyes and fair skin , the Indians repudiated relationship with him , and called him white man -- though they also spoke of him unthinkingly as “ Good Injun . ”

#Text=Because old Wolfbelly himself would grudgingly admit under pressure that the mother of Grant had been the half-caste daughter of Wolfbelly 's sister , white men remembered the taint when they were angry , and called him Injun .

#Text=And because he stood thus between the two races of men , his exact social status a subject always open to argument , not even the fact that he was looked upon by the Harts as one of the family , with his own bed always ready for him in a corner of the big room set apart for the boys , and with a certain place at the table which was called his -- not even his assured position there could keep him from sometimes feeling quite alone , and perhaps a trifle bitter over his loneliness .

#Text=Phoebe Hart had mothered him from the time when his father had sickened and died in her house , leaving Grant there with twelve years behind him , in his hands a dirty canvas bag of gold coin so heavy he could scarce lift it , which stood for the mining claim the old man had just sold , and the command to invest every one of the gold coins in schooling .
#Text=Old John Imsen was steeped in knowledge of the open ; nothing of the great outdoors had ever slipped past him and remained mysterious .
#Text=Put when he sold his last claim -- others he had which promised little and so did not count --
#Text=he had signed his name with an X. Another had written the word John before that X , and the word Imsen after ;
#Text=above , a word which he explained was “ his , ” and below the word “ mark . ”
#Text=John Imsen had stared down suspiciously at the words , and he had not felt quite easy in his mind until the bag of gold coins was actually in his keeping .

#Text=Also , he had been ashamed of that X. It was a simple thing to make with a pen , and yet he had only succeeded in making it look like two crooked sticks thrown down carelessly , one upon the other .
#Text=His face had gone darkly red with the shame of it , and he had stood scowling down at the paper .
#Text=“ That boy uh mine 's goin ' to do better ' n that , by God ! ” he had sworn , and the words had sounded like a vow .

#Text=When , two months after that , he had faced -- incredulously , as is the way with strong men -- the fact that for him life was over , with nothing left to him save an hour or so of labored breath and a few muttered sentences , he did not forget that vow .
#Text=He called Phoebe close to the bed , placed the bag of gold in Grant 's trembling hands , and stared intently from one face to the other .
#Text=“ Mis ' Hart , he ai n't got -- anybody -- my folks -- I lost track of ' em years ago .
#Text=You see to it -- git some learnin ' in his head .
#Text=When a man knows books -- it's -- like bein ' heeled --
#Text=good gun -- plenty uh ca't'idges -- in a fight .
#Text=When I got that gold -- it was like fightin ' with my bare hands -- against a gatlin ' gun .
#Text=They coulda cheated me -- whole thing -- on paper -- I would n't know -- luck -- just luck they did n't .
#Text=So you take it -- and git the boy schoolin ' .
#Text=Costs money -- I know that -- git him all it 'll buy .
#Text=Send him -- where they keep -- the best .
#Text=Do n't yuh let up -- n'er let him --
#Text=whilst they 's a dollar left .
#Text=Put it all -- into his head -- then he ca n't lose it , and he can -- make it earn more .
#Text=An' -- I guess I need n't ask yuh -- be good to him .
#Text=He ai n't got anybody -- not a soul -- Injuns do n't count .
#Text=You see to it -- do n't let up till -- it 's all gone . ”
#Text=Phoebe had taken him literally .

#Text=And Grant , if he had little taste for the task , had learned books and other things not mentioned in the curriculums of the schools she sent him to -- and when the bag was reported by Phoebe to be empty , he had returned with inward relief to the desultory life of the Hart ranch and its immediate vicinity .
#Text=His father would probably have been amazed to see how little difference that schooling made in the boy .

#Text=The money had lasted long enough to take him through a preparatory school and into the second year of a college ; and the only result apparent was speech a shade less slipshod than that of his fellows , and a vocabulary which permitted him to indulge in an amazing number of epithets and in colorful vituperation when the fancy seized him .

#Text=He rode , hot and thirsty and tired , from Sage Hill one day and found Hartley empty of interest , hot as the trail he had just now left thankfully behind him , and so absolutely sleepy that it seemed likely to sink into the sage-clothed earth under the weight of its own dullness .
#Text=Even the whisky was so warm it burned like fire , and the beer he tried left upon his outraged palate the unhappy memory of insipid warmth and great bitterness .
